title: christian couple ban gay men
story: Christian couple ban gay men from buying home - and refuse to let them insideLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell wanted to buy a house but the sellers told them they would not be allowed to even view it as they believe homosexuality is contrary to Gods wordLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell fell in love with the £,, three-bed Image: Triangle NewsByAndy CrickTom ParrySpecial correspondentDanya Bazaraa:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A gay couple who inquired about a house they wanted to buy were banned by the owners from even viewing it as they said homosexuality is “contrary to the word of God”.Luke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell were sent a message from the sellers, who are Christians, citing Bible passages that are used to condemn same-sex relationships.Luke and Lachlan, who have been together for eight years, planned to view the house in Coulsdon, Surrey last Saturday.But on the Wednesday before they got a message back from the sellers via Purplebricks, MailOnline reports.It read: Dear Lachlan and Luke, thank you for sharing your circumstances with us.Weaposre sorrywe seem intrusive, but we just want to make clear that we would be unwilling for two men in a partnership to view or buy our house. Have you had a similar experience  Email webnews@mirrorAs it is contrary to the gracious teaching in Godaposs Word, the Holy Bible, e.g Romans :- and Jude  . With regards.Speaking about his reaction, Luke said: “For the first  seconds I laughed – I thought it was a joke. But then I was upset and I had a cry on the phone to my mum. Homophobia still exists.”Business owner Luke, , and ITV producer Lachlan, , said it was their first attempt to view a house as they look to get on the property ladder. Luke and Lachlan - originally from Adelaide, Australia - are desperate to get their own place after being kept apart during the pandemic, He said: We were separated during Covid, he was in America while I was here, we were forced apart. Buying a house was something that we wanted to do for a long time. But this was the only house we planned for a viewing. We were looking forward to going this weekend.  He added: Since I came out eight years ago I have not come across discirimation. I probably have been discriminated against but was just not aware of it. Luke, of Putney, south west London said they wouldnapost buy or even view the house eventhe owners apologised and changed their mind. He added: We will look for something  now We are not going to let it affect us trying to buy a house.  Married couple Luke Main, , a builder, and medical physicist Dr Joanna Brunker, , own the £,, three-bed home in Coulsdon, South London. Dr Brunker reportedly hit back at the criticism by saying: “We’re practising Christians and are sticking to our beliefs and haven’t done anything wrong.”Luke reported it to the online estate agents who were selling it via Rightmove.They are set to stop selling the property saying the comments from the owners are against its views and values.A Purplebricks spokesperson told them: Thanks for sharing this message Lachlan and weaposre so sorry youaposve had this experience.This stance is completely opposed to our views and values.Weaposll refund this selleraposs fee as Purplebricks no longer wish to list it. A Purplebricks spokesperson added: The sentiments expressed in this message are completely opposed to Purplebricksapos views and values.We have contacted the seller totheir fee and request that they sell their property with a dferent agent.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CrimeGayDaily MirrorHousing,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couples spend 13000 dream home
story: Exclusive: We spent £, on dream extension but cowboy builders left a roofless wreckKylie Thomas, , and husband David, , hired Mark Jones to build their dream £, extension - but their home in Stafford, West Midlands, was left a roofless wreckDavid Thomas, Kylie Thomas and George Turner stand in the unfinished extension Image: SWNSByKate PoundsGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA coupleaposs dream home extension was left a roofless wreck thanks to a botched £, build. Kylie Thomas, , and husband David, , hired Mark Jones, , to build a new room at the rear of their family home last year. The single-storey addition to the property near Stafford, West Midlands, was priced at £, and was supposed to take a fortnight. But months later, the coupleaposs garden still contains a roofless wreck - leaving them feeling stupid and out of pocket. Shocking pictures show half-built brick walls and materials strewn across a muddy patch of ground. A packed green skip overflowing with debris and buckets has been left outside the front of the Staffordshire property.  Kylie and David, who have two children, said Mark asked for money upfront but then went off the radar. And the pair claim that, since the ordeal, they have been told that he wasn’t qualied to do the promised work - and has been involved in similar situations previously. But, when challenged, Mark says he contracted out the work to others - who let him down. Nurse Kylie said: This was a horrendous experience. It sapped our time, money, and energy and left us feeling stupid and upset.  We both work very hard - we worked all through the pandemic. Heaposs taken our money and ruined our garden, and left us with a wreck. When he asked for money I paid it, because it was getting colder and darker and I was worried the work wouldn’t get finishedI didn’t. We knew building materials were running low in the country, so we were really understanding about it.  Kylie and David hired Mark, the director of Chase Home Solutions, to build onto the sitting room of their s townhouse last year. They say he first visited the family home at the end of July and quoted them £,. That cost would cover a three-by-three metre squared pitched roof extension and the replacement of windows in two upstairs rooms, it was said. Kylie said she was impressed by Mark, so signed him up for the job - which he said would take a fortnight.  They scheduled the building work to start on September , and agreed the windows would be replaced beforehand. Kylie says she repeatedly asked about planning permission and building regulations, but Mark said not to worry - because he would sort everything. The trader then asked for £, upfront, with a further £, agreed for when the extension reached roof height.  The next £, would be paid when the roof went on, it was decided, and the final £, when the building had all the electricity in and passed regulations. Kylie says she made the first payment on August  and, when Mark then asked for another £, on August , she paid again. But the builders didnapost show up on the start day - as they were still on another job, according to Mark. And the day after he said they couldnapost come because there was a problem with the skip. Two men finally appeared on September , holding shovels and pushing a wheelbarrow - but claiming Mark had refused to pay for a digger.  Kylie said a bricklayer then arrived and said the extension had not been measured correctly - meaning the couple would have to extend another . metres across the house. This prompted Mark to ask for another £, for the bigger extension, which was paid. But it took the workers a further two weeks to dig and concrete the foundations - because they only showed up for a maximum of four hours a day, Kylie claims. She said: “They told my neighbour they were worked into the ground on ours and working other jobs. They would do a little bit then say they had to go, often they blamed it on the weather.I never saw any materials stored at our property. The lads brought small amounts in the boot of their car. I think he was taking them from other projects. He said he kept them in a lockup, but much later his son told me he didnapost have one. Kylie then paid Mark another £, on September , and another on October . But, by then, the lads were only managing a couple of hours every few days - and Kylie was feeling desperate. She told Mark she felt he had done them over, and he replied that they were having a few problems. The builders never showed again - so Kylie asked for her money back on October . Mark replied to say heaposd call her later and theyaposd work all weekend on her house, she said. But his call never came, and Kylie says that when she now dials the number she used to contact Mark a message says the phone is switched off. Since then, six builders have looked at Kylie’s extension and agree it doesnapost meet building regulations, she said. They say it need to be torn down and should not have amounted to no more than five days effort, it is claimed.  Kylie also alleges that she and David then went to Markaposs flat on October , where a man - estimated to be in his s and calling himself Markaposs son - answered the door. She said: “I explained what had happened and he didn’t know what to do with himself. He said, ‘oh god, not that againapos.Kylie posted on a local Facebook chat and five other families came forward with similar stories.This has been incredibly stressful, she said. Itaposs such a mess, and we donapost have loads of money. People need to be aware that there are cowboys like him out there. Thereaposs no way we could have known - he seemed so professional. I wouldnapost pay all that money upfront again. Every business should have enough in the account to buy materials. When confronted with Kylieaposs claims, Mark said: “During the pandemic I put £, of my own money into starting a building business. I sub-contracted the work and paid them in advance. One build failed an inspection, and another was completely incorrect. It snowballed on social media very quickly. Kylie was one of my customers and I apologised to her mother and offered to put her work right, but they wouldn’t let me. I lost all the contracts and have been left with £, debt and my company is not viable. I really feel for Kylie. The builders have let everyone down. Both have changed their phone numbers and one has closed down his business.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mark Jones" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

news uk-news family-use-kettle-wash-theyve-"Family use kettle to wash after being left with no hot waterByHannah Neary:,  Jan | comments A mum and her three children have been left without hot water and heating since Boxing Day after suffering from constant leaks in their run down home. Care worker Lorraine King, , and her kids have had to wash themselves with hot water from a kettle since their home in West London was damaged by a leak.She told MyLondon: I’ve got to either boil the kettle or even go and take a bath at my daughter’s which is miles away. It’s not convenient.Lorraine, who works in care, said her home, owned by the Catalyst Housing association, has flooded at least once a year since she moved in. She said: It’s happened in the front room three times and also the bedroom, bathroom, toilet. It’s just constant. -  She said the latest incident happened on Boxing Day, when water flooded through the ceiling of her front room where her granddaughter was playing. Lorraine lives with her son and two daughters and they are still waiting for their home to be fixed and claims sheaposs had no advice on when it will be sorted.She also said multiple maintenance workers have come to the property since but no one has fixed the issue and there seems to be poor communication across the company.  She added: The repairs take extra long to do. The guy left us with no hot water or heating. Then they contacted me two weeks later and told me they weren’t aware we didn’t have any heating. They gave us these little oil heaters, which don’t heat up the room at all. The whole house really does smell because of the flood. According to Lorraine, someone came to look at the problem weeks later and turned the electricity back on within a few hours another leak happened.  She said: The whole thing was flooded. There was no advice. I’ve still got no heating or hot water. Every contractor who comes says they don’t know anything about it and they’ve just come to assess it. Clearly they’re not communicating. Lorraine said she is worried a family member could be electrocuted because of the damp conditions and the stress of the repeated leaks is affecting her mental health. She said: It’s happened so much, I’m now having mental health issues and I never had this before I moved into the property. On Saturday, I had a total meltdown because I just couldn’t handle it any more and I’ve still got to come into work. I can’tproperly because I don’t feel myself.  Lorraine says she was on the housing waiting list for  years before she moved into her first permanent home in Kensington and Cha in . But she said the new build has had so many defects she almost cannot stand to live there any more. She said: Eventhey repair it I’m not comfortable in that property because I’ll decorate it and it’ll be ruined again. A spokesperson for Catalyst said: “We are sorry for the inconvenience and distress caused. We believe the source of the current problem is a leaking communal heating pipe in Ms King’s ceiling. title: historic street could renamed after
story: Calls for offensive road name to be changed after two visitors complainLton Parish Council has written to residents after two visitors to the village complained of the name of Darkey Lane and have askedthey want to change it or notResidents in Lton, Devon are being askedthey want to change the name of the road Darkey Lane Image: Google.MapsByAnita MerrittAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Residents in a Devon village are facing calls to change the offensive name of a road after complaints made by two visitors. Lton Parish Council has written to residents about the complaints of aposDarkey Laneapos and have askedthey want to change it or not. If residents choose to rename the road, it would be the responsibility of West Devon Borough Councilwhich would then do their own consultationa desire for change was expressed, DevonLive reports. The letter from January  reads: I have been asked to write to you on behalf of Lton Parish Council following receipt of a complaint about the street name Darkey Lane made by two visitors to the village. What do you think about this story  Let us know in the comments below  The visitors, one of who is of Caribbean heritage, were shocked and extremely upset having been confronted with a name like this. Councillors took the decision at a parish council meeting on November , , to undertake a public consultation with you in early January , to find outyou would like to keep or change the existing road name. It went on to explain that to rename the road, two-thirds of households on Darkey Lane would have to be in agreement. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Furthermore,they wanted to change the name then each household would have to pay £ to WDBC. The parish council have offered to pay for replacement road signs. Residents on the road would also be required to tell utility companies and all professional and personal contacts regarding any new road name. In the same letter, the parish council gave historical context on how the road got its name. It said: Darkey Lane was a historic, locally-based road name given before development in the local area. The road had originally been a sunken and tree-lined dark lane. Over the years and with the use of local Devonshire dialect, it became known as Darkey Lane. Robert Fleming, the owner of Lton Hall Hotel, is in favour of changing the roadaposs name. He said: I agree that the name should be changed. I think historically that the lane may have been called Darke Lane in the old English spelling, as indeed the lane is very dark and tree covered in places. The fact that the word ‘darkey’ has negative connotations, and has and continues to be used as such, supersedes historical spellings where they may have had a dferent meaning. People may be offended so it should be changed as standard, with a minimum of fuss. Indeed as a hotelier in the area, we have had people actually mention their surprise at the name of the lane as it is quite close to us. When I moved here  years ago I remember being rather shocked at it as we had moved down from London and lived in a multi-racial area of East London. Lton can not by any stretch of the imagination be classed as multi-racial. For people objecting to the change, I thinkthey could imagine themselves as being in a minority of some sort and then have a derogatory work on a street name that affected  upset them it may garner a dferent response. The name could be just Darke Lane or even Dark Lane which is minimal effort. In this advanced age we live in it should be a simple matter to change all the databases etc, although people may decide to live with it as it means changing passport  drivers licences and so on which obviously will incur some costs. Lton Parish Council said the results of the consultation will be reported at its next meeting later this month on January . story: How much money will my childs school lose  Use our interactive tool to find outAs new Department of Education figures suggest thousands of schools in England will face a cut to their funding next year, our interactive widget tells you how much money your childs school will loseNew figures suggest thousands of schools in England potentially face a real-terms cut to their funding next year Image: Getty ImagesByAnnie GoukKatie L Wilson:,  Jan | commentsNew figures suggest thousands of schools in England potentially face a real-terms cut to their funding next year. The Department for Educationhas published provisional figures on funding for mainstream schools in the - financial year, based on the National Funding Formula . These figures are subject to revision and are not necessarily what schools will actually receive, since they are based on pupil data from -.Use our interactive widget to explore this projected funding for your school - and see how this compares both locally and nationally:The Government has committed to giving schools an increase in their pupil-led funding of at least .% per pupil.However, this is below the Office for Budget Responsibility’s most recent inflation projection of .% - meaning nearly , state-funded schools are projected to see a real-terms cut in their funding.The figures also show that there are huge dferences in the amount of money state schools receive per pupil, even between those in the same area. These figures exclude specialist SEN schools, as these are funded dferently to other schools. It includes both maintained schools, which are overseen by the local authority, and academies, which operate independently and receive their funding directly from the Education and Skills Funding Agency. Generally, funding is made up of a basic lump sum that all schools of that level are entitled to, plus funding on top of that based on the number of pupils, and extra money for pupils with additional needs - such as those living in deprivation. There are also other funding streams that relate to things like geographical isolation and expected growth in pupil numbers. The process was set to be formalised by , with all local authorities moving to the National Funding Formula, but as a result of signicant challenges, the Government has delayed its implementation. As such, local authorities currently decide how money is shared out between schools in its area, using its own funding formula based on DfE guidance. story: Huge Dover lorry queue so long you can see it on Google Maps amid Brexit check delaysImages from Google Satellite imagery show hundreds of lorries lining the roads around the Port of Dover after months of chaos delaying crossingsThe huge queues are visible on Google satellite images Image: GoogleByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments Lorry queues from the Port of Dover are now so long the huge tailbacks are appearing on Google satellite images.Images from space show hundreds of lorries lining the roads around the port after months of chaos delaying crossings.The delays are being blamed on extra controls which have come into place following Brexit.Port chiefs have urged the UK Government to hold talks with the EU on ways to ease further checks which are set to come into force later this year. It is feared the added checks could be disastrous for the already chaotic situation.One courier said he had been caught up in queues of up to km since full customs controls came into force at beginning of January, reportsThe Independent. The British haulier each driver was having to undergo around  minutes of checks before being allowed to pass. He said: It’s entirely Brexit – you can’t blame it on anything  but Brexit,” said the driver, who has had to push back some deliveries. The Dover TAP, a temporary traffic system to prevent a build-up in lorry traffic, was brought in amid tailbacks. The TAP has also put in place a mph speed restriction for all vehicles approaching the port.  Covid checks are also taking up time at the port - with Chief Executive saying more lateral flow tests are needed for staff.Bannister told the BBC : The Government has made lateral flow capacity available to some key areas. They havenapost stepped as deeply into our operations as weaposd like them to.He said port workers had maintained the operations and the critical flow of goods into the nation over the past two years and the port needs to be better prepared. He added daily tests would ensure the port has the right complements of the people on the ground to facilitate travel. title: i spent years washing cars
story: I spent years washing cars to make cash - now I own a £m business empireSam White spent her childhood in an unstable home and had to find a job at  to make ends meet - now she heads up her own £m motor insurance claims empireSam White credits her success, in part, to her lestyle overhaul Image: David HarrisonByZahna EklundAudience writerSaffron Otter:,  Jan | commentsMany of us have dreams of being our own boss and starting our own businesses, and one woman has been able to make her dreams a reality with the help of a complete lestyle overhaul.Sam White, , spent her teenage years washing cars in order to make ends meet, as she grew up in a dysal home and knew from a young age she needed to be independent.Speaking to the Manchester Evening News, she said: “Because my childhood was so unstable, I always wanted and needed to be independent and I didn’t feel like working for someone  gave me that, my future would still rely on someone .“I was washing cars when I was   to make cash, I always needed to have that feeling I could take care of myself and no one could take it away from me. That drive has stuck with me.” Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. At the age of , the woman started her first business from a desk in her sisteraposs conservatory - but she was struggling with a panic disorder at the time and would find comfort in junk food, which led her to follow an unhealthy lestyle.The entrepreneur, from Cheadle, Greater Manchester, added: “I set my first company up from my sister’s conservatory when I was .“I suffered badly with panic attacks, four or five a day, it was a full-blown panic disorder. It was a vicious cycle of me wanting comfort in junk food anything that was bad for me and anything to do with exercise I was horried by.“I was eating to suppress those feelings. But I always had success at work, consistent promotions, it was my one safe place.” Samaposs first business was a motor claims management company called Action and after the company reached a steady point a few years later, she decided to go travelling - and in the process, completely changed her outlook on le.The woman said the dramatic change of scenery helped her mental health signicantly, and she was even able to cut junk food out of her diet - dropping her from a size  to a size  by the time she ed to the UK.Sam - who has Harry, six, and Frankie, eight, with her ex-we and is planning to undergo IVF treatment to welcome another child with her spouse Jennie Guay - now says she no longer suffers from panic attacks at all, and credits exercise with helping to solve so many problems.She said: “It took me a few years after I got back [from travelling] to make it into something I do consistently. It doesn’t have to be major, just something to get the blood pumping around the body. For me, it solves so many problems.And the business mogul believes changing her lestyle also helped her succeed in her career - as she is no longer scared of making decisions or speaking in public.This year, Sam aims to grow one of the companies under her Freedom Services Group umbrella - Stella Insurance - which she set up in Australia, designed completely for women.With each policy, the business donates  to a domestic abuse charity, and plans are underway to launch in the UK.The now-millionaire said: “In my wildest dreams, I wouldn’t have thought it could become the size that it has. title: i stranded aa said cant
story: I was stranded but AA said they cant prioritise lone women as "thats equality"Dr Helen Motts experience sparked backlash on twitter after she postied about her exchange with the AA, who twice told her they offer no priority to lone women who feel they are vulnerableDr Helen Mott was appalled by what she was told by the AA on Wednesday Image: Barbara Evripidou Bristol PostBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan | comments A worried woman says the AA are putting lives at risk after being told they refuse to prioritise lone females on the roadside at night because aposthataposs equalityapos. Dr Helen Mott slammed the breakdown rescue service after she was advised they do not base call outs solely on someoneaposs sex or gender.The -year-old was stranded on Wednesday and says she feared for her safety. With the evening fast approaching, the anxious mum told the operator she felt she was in a vulnerable position. She was stunned when they told her that she had to wait her turn - as they donapost give any kind of priority to those who consider themselves at risk.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  The British motoring association has drawn heavy criticism on social media for its stance. After tweeting about the exchange it provoking anger from other female motorists as the AA were forced into an apology.Dr Mott told The Sun : “The operator gave me an estimated time which was knocking on for a couple of hours.“I asked the call handler why they treated men and women the same and didn’t prioritise lone women. They said there’s no dference and they just said that’s equality. They’ve been trained to say it.”  After being picked up an AA truck less than an hour later, she tweeted the AA to confirm what she was told over the phone was the companyaposs official policy. They said: Hi Helen, youaposve been advised correctly. We donapost prioritise based on gender, we do consider the location so as an example we would prioritise someone on a motorway over someone in a supermarket carpark. Other twitter users expressed their outrage and women’s safety campaigners criticised the AAaposs stance. Sophie Francis-Cansfield, of Women’s Aid, was quoted as saying she believed womenaposs safety should be prioritised, as one is murdered by a man every three days in the UK.The AA later doubled down, and its president Edmund King intervened on Twitter and said the group does prioritise vulnerable customers after all.When askedthe motoring association makes no dference between a aposstranded female driver and a stranded maleapos, King said: Of course we do, and we use common sense and prioritise women but by the letter of the law we canapost say that. He later claried: It hasnapost changed. The wording of our initial response not great and we apologised. We prioritise anyone at risk but more often than not it will be lone women. In breakdowns involving lone women where there is any concern raised they receive the highest level of care and priority. Another AA spokesperson told the Mirror: We accept that the wording of our initial response wasn’t great and have apologised. In fact, we prioritise anyone at risk but more often than not it will be lone women. In breakdowns involving lone women where there is any concern raised by the customer, they receive the highest level of care and priority. title: mum 27 told not see
story: Mum, , told she may not live to babys birthday after tired, bloated feelingEstelle Wignall has defiantly insisted she is up for the fight and has launched a fundraising campaign to seek treatment for her oian cancer and terminal illness overseasYoung mum Estelle Wignall with husband Mike Image: Focus FeaturesByAnn CusackGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A young mum fighting cancer has been warned she will not see her daughter’s next birthday. Estelle Wignall has stage four oian cancer which recently spread to her bowel and doctors have told her she is terminally ill.A mum to baby daughter, Brooke,  months, she has been offered palliative care.But Estelle insists she is up for the fight, and has launched a fundraising campaign through GoFundMe to seek treatment overseas.She says: “I feel as though I have been written off, but I am not ready to throw in the towel yet. I’ve bounced back before, and I am determined to do it again. To help Estelle raise money for treatment overseas, you can donate here. I want to celebrate my little girl’s second birthday, I want to see her start school, I want to mark as many milestones as I can.” Estelle, , from Wigan, Greater Manchester, was diagnosed with oian cancer five years ago after becoming tired and bloated. Doctors at first insisted she had IBS but her symptoms became so bad that she was rushed to hospital and then sent home again with medication. She said: “I picked up a leaflet in hospital about oian cancer and I immediately diagnosed myself. But everyone told me not to be so stupid because I was only  years old. “People said I was being a hypochondriac. Nobody took me seriously – but I just knew. It was an instinct.” Estelle pushed for tests and in February , she was finally diagnosed with grade one oian cancer. She had a tumour removed, along with her right oy and Fallopian tube. After making a full recovery, she put the cancer behind her, working as a receptionist and marrying soulmate Mike, , in June  in Texas. The couple had their first child, Brooke, in May . Estelle said: “I had only one oy and so to conceive so quickly felt like a miracle. I didn’t have my regular checks because I was pregnant, and during the birth the midwe actually noticed nodules on my cervix and I was referred for more tests, which came back clear. “We adored Brooke and the future looked fantastic.  “I was actually planning a hysterectomy so that there was no chance the cancer could .” But before her op, Estelle started to feel unwell, suffering from exhaustion and a lack of appetite. She said: “I had started the  week diet challenge, to get rid of my baby weight. I just needed to lose a stone, that was all. “But I started to feel very tired and I had no appetite. I thought it was all due to the diet – but it got worse and I began to think the cancer might be back.” In November , she was sent for urgent scans and was diagnosed with stage four cancer, which had spread to her liver and lungs.  She said: “I was devastated. The first time I had cancer, I coped well. But this time, because of Brooke, I was heartbroken. She was just six months old and it felt so cruel. I had only just started being a mum, and I didn’t want it to be taken away. She was initially told her le expectancy was only two or three years but her outlook improved after treatment and a raft of alternative therapies. “There have been points when I felt I could not go on. I considered euthanasia. But I kept going, and I got my spirits up again, she said. A recent scan showed the cancer has spread once again to the bowel and Estelle is now being warned that her time is fast running out. She says: “I’ve been on the brink before and I have bounced back and I am determined to do it again. I can’t give up, I have too much to live for, and I am determined to look for treatment abroad. “I hope also that my story can help other women, it is so important, no matter how young you are, to follow your instincts and to insist on answers. Don’t be fobbed off – it could cost you your le.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Oian cancerCancerHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Mum, , tragically took her own le after battling delayed postnatal depressionLisa Cook, , gave birth to her daughter in  but started to exhibit mental health issues after splitting with the childs father six years later, an inquest heardLisa Cook took her own le after battling delayed postnatal depression Image: Lisa Cook  Cavendish PressLtdByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A mum-of-one took her own le after battling a delayed post-natal depression years after she gave birth, an inquest heard.Lisa Cook, , gave birth to her daughter in  but only exhibited mental health issues six years later after splitting with the childaposs father. The HMRC client advisor received treatment but repeatedly made attempts on her le. Lisa also drank up to six bottles of wine a day, had a four-week stint in a rehabilitation clinic and was assessed by healthcare professionals. She vowed she had beat her illness. On July , Lisaaposs boyfriend found her hanged at the home near Oldham, Greater Manchester following concerns for her welfare. Tests revealed she had so much alcohol in her bloodstream that she would have been almost three times the drink driving limit. Lisa had no health problems earlier in le.  She studied Leisure and Tourism at college worked and for a telecoms company before getting a job with HMRC. Linda Rees, her mum, said in a statement: She had a child with her partner but they split in  and it was a dficult time for Lisa. Lisa and her daughter moved in with me and I believed she suffered from delayed post-natal depression. Eventually Lisa moved out and her daughter moved in with her father although everyone was on good terms. During the time Lisa was living with me, I noticed she was drinking a lot more alcohol - up to six bottles of wine per day. Sadly it was to mask her depression. In  she went into rehab for four weeks but I donapost think it worked because she continued to drink. Linda continued: She was sectioned for one week and diagnosed with bipolar, anxiety and depression.  The heartbroken mum said: When she was not drinking, she seemed fine and happy. She talked about feeling suicidal in the  months prior to her death. She would say the only thing stopping her from taking her le was me and her daughter. On July , I rang Lisa and woke her up. Later, she texted and she made some comment askingmy sandwich was more important than her and I told her to grow up. The next morning you sent her a text message but got no response. Later I received a call about the sad news that Lisa had passed away. Danny Howarth, who had been dating Lisa since November , said: She worked from home and was at high risk due to her medical condition. She would have very good and bad days when she would feel trapped. She had had demons from past concerns with her mental health. She hated taking her medication and when she felt better, she would stop. Sometimes she was her own worst enemy. I kept a diary of how she was and she was a binge drinker and could drink one or two bottles of wine or vodka a day.  At times, she would make threats to take her own le. I once rushed to her aid and found her with a kne. But on the weekend before she died, we talked about getting a house together and going on holiday. On the day before it happened, she told me she had a run-in with her mother. She was emotional and told her mother she was feeling suicidal and that her mother told her to grow up. The following day I sent a text message but I started to panic when she had not replied by .pm. I arrived at the house at .pm to see her slumped over in the corner of the lounge. When police arrived at the house, they found ious packs of antidepressants going back to  which had barely been taken,at all. Officers also found an empty bottle of pink gin and a half-full bottle of vodka. She had  milligrams of alcohol per  millilitres of blood in her system. The alcohol limit for driving in blood is mg. Recording a conclusion of suicide coroner Matthew Cox said: Lisa had tried to stop drinking and when that happened she was fine and happy but sadly the occasions where she tried to stop were not successful. Her mother talked about her being suicidal prior to her death. It is clear that Lisa was responsible for taking her own le. Delayed postpartum depression, also known as late-onset postpartum depression, can affect women up to  months after delivery, according to experts. It can even appear later than that in some women, depending on the hormonal changes that occur after having a baby.If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . story: Mum, , sheds st and chucks old swimsuit away after family creates own fat loss dietEmma Scrivener, , from Swansea, Wales, and her family shed an impressive st in just months after inventing their own clean living dietEmma Scrivener, husband Tony, their daughter Katie Thomas and husband Shaun invented the diet Image: DA GroupByAndrea Blazquez:,  Jan | comments A family lost a combined  stone between them after coming up with their own diet.Emma Scrivener, , her husband Tony, their daughter mum-of-three Katie Thomas and husband Shaun created a plan that they say is easy to stick to. Emma, from Swansea, Wales, explained she was a size  when she decided to lose weight following a health scare.My blood pressure was extremely high and I had problems with my back and realised that something had to be done before I got progressively worse, she told the . Also we had been on a holiday and after seeing myself in a swimsuit realised I had piled on the weight.Have you been through a weight loss journey like Emma and her family  Let us know at webnews@mirror I had to make the decision that I would do nothing and regret it later or make the changes before it became too late. She went on to say she never expected to drop down to a size , but knewshe could get to a size  she would be very happy. What has become known as the DA diet consists of most foods, including treats like chocolate, crisps and cake.  But is about portion control. Emma said many people may be eating well but eating far too much. Her plan is well balanced with the correct amounts of protein, fats and carbohydrates.  It took her around  months to reach her target weight, losing five stone, as she was going through menopause. story: Pensioner, , with dementia left in AE waiting room for  hours after collapsingWendy Parsons, , was pictured slumped in a chair in AE at Arrowe Park Hospital in Wirral, Merseyside, during her -hour wait for a bed after falling at homeWendy Parsons, , waited for  hours slumped in a chair in AE Image: Liverpool EchoByJonathan HumphriesRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan | comments An OAP was left slumped in a hospital waiting room chair for  hours after collapsing at home.Shocking photos show retired carer and mum-of-three Wendy Parsons at Arrowe Park Hospital in Wirral, Merseyside, waiting for a bed following the fall and bang to the head.The -year-old had been discharged from the hospital the previous afternoon, having been admitted with a suspected infection, reports the Liverpool Echo. Wendyaposs son Roger - who has been staying with his mum - found her lying on the floor at her home in Wallasey in the early hours of Wednesday. Daughter Colette Clarke has accused the hospital of giving the pensioner an unsafe discharge during her visit earlier in the week.Have you experienced a y waiting time in AE  Let us know at webnews@mirror  Wendy was admitted last Saturdayfeeling completely zonked out and appearing confused, her daughter said. With her infection markers having reduced, she was allowed to go home on Tuesday evening but was up all night. Collette said Roger found their mum on the floor around am the following day. The room looked like a tornado had been through it, I think she had thrown everything around in her confusion, she explained. Collette, who lives nearby, went on to say her mum is very blasé about her health despite suffering with arthritis, COPD and heart failure.But was nowhere near her baseline when staff allowed her to leave the hospital hours earlier. It became clear Wendy had suffered a bang to her head, which later developed into a large bruise. Colette drove her mum to AE later that morning as she seemed delirious.  Wendy was taken for CT scans and an X-ray but then was sent back to the waiting room until midnight before a bed became available, she said. Colette said it is a disgusting way to treat an elderly woman with multiple ailments. She praised those staff who saw her mum, calling them fantastic but said she has concerns about theof time she had to wait considering how frail she is. She questioned why the AE facilities went through a £m+ upgrade when they donapost have the staff to manage the space they have  In a recent inspection by healthcare watchdog the Care Quality Commission , concerns were raised about the way patients were dealt with in the hospitalaposs emergency department. The report noted there were not always enough staff to care for patients and not all those available had training in key skills required or could always identy and quickly act upon patients at risk of deterioration.A spokesperson for Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Trust said: We endeavour to ensure we provide patients with the best possible care in our hospitals and while we can’t discuss details of inidual patients, we can offer assurance that we have robust processes in place to ensure patients are discharged safely.Each patient is thoroughly assessed and provided with a care plan on discharge. Like other Trusts nationally we are experiencing an extremely busy period in our Emergency Department and we therefore prioritise those patients who are in the most urgent need of care which regretfully can mean a longer wait for some of our other patients. Our Senior Nursing Team will be in contact with the family to offer support, investigate their concerns and ensure that any lessons are learnt to improve patient experience. story: Prince Andrew made staff line up his  teddies in size order, ex-palace maid claimsCharlotte Briggs worked for the Royal Family in the mid-s also claimed the Duke of Yorks two favourite teddies were placed on mahogany thrones at his bedsidePrince Andrew reportedly had staff arrange his teddy collection in size order, a former palace maid has claimed Image: Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew aposs teddies had to be lined up in size order and it took staff an entire day to be trained on how to arrange them on his bed, a former palace maid has claimed.Charlotte Briggs worked for the Royal Family in the mid-s has claimed it took her half an hour to arrange the  teddies correctly before the prince went to bed.Charlotte, , reportedly said: “As soon as I got the job, I was told about the teddies and it was drilled into me how he wanted them. “I even had a day’s training. Everything had to be just right. It was so peculiar.” She added: “But he absolutely loved the ­teddies and was very clear about how he wanted them arranged.”Charlotte also told The Sun that staff were given a diagram on how to place his cuddly toys around his room.It reportedly included instructions on the placements of five of his favourite stuffed animals. Charlotte, who was  at the time, said that while she worked for the Duke of York there were  teddies she arranged every day. The Dukeaposs teddies were arranged on the floor in a pre-allocated spot in his room before bed. The biggest teddies were put at the back and the rest were in descending order of size to the smallest at the front. The princeaposs two favourite teddies were placed on mahogany thrones at his bedside, Charlotte claimed. She further said the vast majority of teddies were dressed as sailors, in unorms and caps, and came from all over the world.  Charlotte claimed that the prince frequently lost his temper with the staff, especiallyit involved his cuddly toys. She added: It took me half an hour to arrange them — most bizarre thing to be paid for. Andrew, , is now living with ex-we Sarah Ferguson at Royal Lodge in Windsor, but a suite of rooms was kept for him at the palace for overnight stays. It is understood his palace bedroom has been packed up and his teddy collection has been scaled back.  The allegations of the princeaposs bizarre requests come as more claims say the prince sketched out a plan for how his five teddies and cuddly toys should be positioned on his bed every night.It was said he would “scream and shout”his servants failed to place them exactly how he wanted at Buckingham Palace, ex protection officer Paul Page tells ITV ’s Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile.A handwritten guide is said to have included two hippos, a black panther and bears, as well as three cushions called aposDaddyapos, aposDucksapos and aposPrinceapos. It showed exactly where to place blankets, as well as five toys and a fur, which had ribbons that had to hang off the side of the bed. Page worked in Royalty and Specialist Protection Command between  and  and had access to the princeaposs private quarters.In this apartment, the Duke had a bed piled high with stuffed animals and toys, Page claims. He said: “It had about  or  stuffed toys positioned on the bed and basically there was a card the inspector showed us in a drawer and it was a picture of these bears all in situ. “The reason for the laminated picture wasthose bears weren’t put back in the right order by the maids, he would shout and scream.” Thecontacted the palace and Andrewaposs representatives for a comment. He will no longer be able to use the title of His Royal Highness.The action was taken after a judge decided he would have to face a civil trial on sex abuse allegations made by Virginia Giuffre.The Duke of York vehemently denies the allegations. Ms Briggs told the outlet when she started working for him, Andrew was  and had just orced Fergie while also a veteran of the Falklands War.  She said: “This man fought for his country in the Falklands but couldn’t stand up to close his own curtains. It was utterly ridiculous but spoke volumes about him. Andrew definitely put a downer on things. He thinks he’s above everyone.” Ms Briggs told how she had moved from Yorkshire for the job and Andrew was based on the “nursery floor” where he and his siblings had grown up. She said that despite being an adult he wouldn’t do anything for himself. “There were two of us and we worked on a rota from .am to .am and then later on in the evening. We’d turn down his bed, remove his teddies, do the curtains and lay out his pyjamas. But he was a bad apple and behaved like a spoiled brat, she claimed. “Really you weren’t actually meant to be seen, you’d just sneak in and do stuff. But he was a bit lazy and he would call down from his office and say, ‘can you send the maid to shut the curtains’. They were literally behind him and massive — from floor to ceiling and as high as a house but he refused to get up and close them himself. She said that it was frustrating as she couldnapost say anything and being only -years-old she would cry about what was happening. Ms Briggs claimed he was worse than ladies-in-waiting who would get up and do some things for themselves. But she added the other royals like Charles and Edward were lovely. story: Sunbed addict mum bravely shows off bald patch after skin cancer left hole in her headWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Childminder Nickie Murtagh, , used sunbeds twice a week but after discovering a dry patch on her scalp she was diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma, a form of skin cancerNickie Murtagh decided to see her doctor after a dry patch on her scalp turned into a lump Image: Nickie Murtagh   CATERS NEWSByBeth KilgallonSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan | comments A former sunbed addict has been left with a bald patch after skin cancer left a hole in her head. Nickie Murtagh, , a childminder from London, used the beds twice a week before discovering a dry patch on her scalp. It soon turned into a lump and she raced to the doctor before hearing the news she had basal cell carcinoma, a form of skin cancer. Since successfully having the lump removed and a skin graft from her thigh, mum-of-three Nickie has been left with a bald patch on her scalp which she says looked like she has been shot in the head. Nickie now wears SPF all year round and wants to raise awareness of the dangers that sunbeds and sun damage can cause to your skin.Were you aware of this  Join the discussion in the comment section  She said: When I was in my twenties I would use a lot of sunbeds. I went a couple of times a week and would go on for about eight to  minutes. I didnapost exceed the recommended, so I didnapost think too much of it. I would also avoid using sun cream, especially on my face, because I didnapost want to stop myself from catching a tan. I thought that sun cream would stop me tanning, which I know now isnapost the case. First of all, I noticed a dry patch on my scalp which eventually turned into a lump in my parting line. I went to the doctors to get it checked out but they told me it was fine and nothing to worry about. I then went on holiday to Tenere and it got much worse. I was also getting bad melasma on my face and my tan was very patchy. My skin just didnapost feel right at all. After ing from her holiday, Nickie went back to the doctors where she says she was told, once again, that everything was fine. But the lump on her head was making her self-conscious, so she decided to go back to the doctors because she wanted it removed whether it was cancer or not. Nickie said: The doctors told me it was a cosmetic procedure and I would have to pay for it. I got really upset and eventually, they sent a referral to the dermatologist. After an appointment with the dermatologist, they told me they thought it was cancer straight away and biopsied me there and then. While waiting for the results, my family stayed so positive and reassured me it was going to be fine and although the dermatologist thought it was cancer, I still wasnapost really expecting it. Seven weeks later I received the results and I was told it was skin cancer - basal cell carcinoma. When I heard the C word I instantly felt like my world was ending and I was going to die. I worried about my kids and my family. It was terrying. I was offered radiotherapy or surgery. I chose surgery because it was less invasive and avoids the side effects that come with radiotherapy. I just wanted it to be gone. So I had surgery to remove the cancer and a skin graft from my thigh which was successful and I was given the all-clear. Nickie says that the skin graft was the worst part of her experience as her thigh would not stop bleeding. After having the staples removed from the area that the lump was removed from, she says that it was so gruesome and shocking. Nickie added: It was awful. It looked like I had been shot in the head. And I was terried to wash my hair and make it worse. My hair hasnapost and wonapost grow back in that area because the skin is from my thigh. And I have also lost all feeling in it. I canapost see it very well because it is on the top of my head, but it makes me feel self-conscious when I catch people staring at it or sometimes kids point it out. I try to use it to teach them a lesson to wear hats and sun cream. I also donapost like to wear shorts because people can see the scar on my leg from the skin graft. I am so much more cautious in the sun now and I avoid sunbeds at all cost. I am much more educated about sun damage and sun protection. I always wear a hat and I have SPF on every single day of the year. The sun doesnapost have to be hot to cause damage. title: teen handed 15 year sentence
story: Teen handed -year sentence for stabbing of Reece Tansey, , in planned attackReece Tansey was stabbed in the early hours of May , , in Bolton before going on to desperately bang on the door of a nearby house to plead for helpPolice arrived at the scene minutes later and Reece was rushed to Salford Royal Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at .am Image: MEN MEDIAByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan A teenage attacker who was found guilty of murdering Bolton schoolboy Reece Tansey has been handed a -year sentence. Another boy, found guilty of manslaughter for his part in the brutal stabbing of -year-old Reece, was jailed for six years. A court heard that the attackers - named Boy A and Boy B for legal reasons - had agreed to meet up in the early hours of May  in Walker Avenue, Bolton, because of an escalating dispute between Boy B and a friend of the victim. But when Reece arrived he was stabbed six times by Boy A. He banged on the door of a nearby house desperately pleading for help before falling to the ground. And, having been discovered by two men, he used his final breath to tell them the names of his killers.  Police arrived at the scene minutes later and Reece was rushed to Salford Royal Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at .am. A pathologist concluded his death was caused by multiple stab wounds, which were likely to have been inflicted by a kne with a -cm blade. After fleeing the scene, Boy A sent a Snapchat video of himself carrying a kne covered in blood, accompanied by the word muppet. He later sent a message to Boy B, which read: I thought it only went through his coat so I kept doing it. Adding: Heaposs dead now. Boy B responded with a laughing emoji.  Both teenagers appeared at a sentencing hearing at Manchester Crown Court todaywhere judge Justice Farbey was told there was a long-standing hate between Boy B and Reece, and Boy A had been brought into the dispute as support. During a three-week trial, jurors heard that the two boys had goaded Reece and his friend into meeting them, but he was initially reluctant. The court heard he had sent a message to his friend, which read: Getting brought into your s* again. Ainapost in no f**** mood. All four boys eventually agreed to meet that night and Reece left home and headed to the rendezvous point near Great Lever Park. But as Reece was en route, his friend informed him that he had decided to stay in bed.  Before the trial Boy A admitted to killing Reece but denied murder. Boy B admitted he was there but denied killing Reece or knowing Boy A had a kne. Richard Wright QC, who represented Boy A in the trial, told the court how the dispute was part of a petty subculture brought on via social media. Mr Wright said: It is a fact that they were all young people and a fact that their culture, that all of them engaged in, driven by social media led to them meeting up. He added: It might be said that all were particularly vulnerable due to their age, from being drawn into this petty sub-culture of social media interactions and bravado. They were all vulnerable to that and unfortunately one of them lost their le.  In a victim statement read out in court, Reeceaposs mum Laura said: Reece was our -year-old son, he made us smile, he made us laugh, he made us tear our hair out at times, a typical teenage lad, but he was ours. Reece was fiercely protective of his mum and little brother and saw himself as the man of the house. His dad saw him as his best friend. Reece was simply our world, and his death has devastated us beyond belief. Boy A was handed a -year-old sentence while Boy B was jailed for six years.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Court caseHospitalsCrown courtMurder trialCrimeTeenagersKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news worried-voters-plan-keep-face-"Boris Johnson confirms Plan B Covid measures will end on January ByJeremy ArmstrongNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Worried voters in Englandaposs Covid- aposhotspotsapos claim Boris Johnson is risking lives by reducing coronavirus restrictions - to save his own political skin. The North East of England has suffered some of the countryaposs highest Covid infection rates in . Experts say it is an Omicron hotspot after the outbreak moved north from London.The region was home to seven of the  local authorities with the highest infection rates this month. One in  peoplein the region tested positive in the week to January , the highest of any point in the pandemic.  The alarming rate of infection was highest in Middlesbrough with , cases per , people. Stockton came in third in England, Hartlepool fourth and Redcar fth in UK Health Security Agency research. Today education chiefs, politicians and ordinary voters united to condemn the Governmentaposs lting of compulsory mask wearing and working from home rules. Former steel worker Barry Heseltine, , of Redcar, North Yorkshire, said: He is lting the restrictions to save his own skin.  He is doing this to take away from the trouble he is in. But we will wear the masks for a while yet. His we Joyce, , added: I voted for him but he shot himself in the foot. He probably thinks it will blow over like everything . I thought he did well at first. Not now. Retired telephonist Patricia Blackett, , from Thornaby on Teesside, was wearing a mask and would continue to do so indoors at crowded venues like cinemas and theatres.  She added: I think the Prime Minister is trying to appease us and the people in the party. He is trying to take attention away from what he has done.Butyou have lost a loved one I donapost think that you will forget that and vote for him again. He has lost all credibility. I voted Tory but I am all for Keir Starmer now.He is a smart lawyer, a QC. I think that I will vote for him next time, the same goes for my daughter and son. Sixth formers Faith Lucas and Jessica Brown, both  and from Brotton, East Cleveland, are both planning to wear masks even after the Government lts the restriction.  Jessica, a psychology, business and law student, said: I think that I will keep on wearing one into the summer when it will become more dficult when it is hot. I think Boris is guilty of double standards with parties, he asked us to stick to the rules, but he did not do that himself. Faith added: You need to keep masks in enclosed spaces, especially on transport. I am not involved in politics just yet but obviously he should not have been having a party in lockdown. I know there is now a lot of pressure on him.Mum-of-two Pauline Collins, , of Middlesbrough, vowed to continue mask-wearing while shopping, on buses and on trains. I am not really sure about Boris Johnson, she said.I do think he should not be lting the restrictions completely. You should wear them on public transport and places like shopping centres. It is dferent for the young, they are not as worried about it as us oldies.  Singer John Rowland, , a dad-of-three who worked in Spain, Greece, Holland, Germany, Italy and Gibraltar before setting up as a busker in Middlesbrough town centre  years ago, said there is no saving Boris Johnson. Pardon the language, he has been a cluster****, he told the Mirror. It has gone too far for him now so it does not matter what he does. You look at other countries that have dealt with Covid so much better. I have friends in New Zealand, their leaders have handled it properly. He told how his we Hayley, , and children Grace, , Alex,, and eight-year-old Noah all went down with Covid before Christmas. He added: My we works in a school and got the Delta strain  months ago and she was really ill, and then we all got what was probably the Omicron iant. I was not at deathaposs door, it was like a bad flu virus. But I would not wish it on anybody, we have seen so many people lose loved ones.  Middlesbrough Labour MP Andy McDonald said his office was inundated with voters complaining about Boris Johnson. They are expressing their sheer anger at him. Welsh leader Mark Drayford summed it up, he said. He is being guided by the data and public health priorities, we are being driven by politics. I would be guided by the professionals who think we should maintain our guard for a little longer. On masks, people will make their own minds up and I support them fully on that. Chris Zarraga, director of campaign group Schools North East, said: Schools are still facing real challenges in getting staff cover, increasing staff workload and stress. story: Laundry experts claim were definitely not washing our bed sheets enoughHygiene experts have revealed that keeping your bed clean and washing your sheets more often can help thwart germs and allergens, and has even been found to help you sleep betterYou might not be washing your sheets enoughImage: Getty Images Image SourceBySusan KnoxShowbiz and Entertainment Reporter:,  Jan | commentsItaposs an easy task to forget at the best of times, but you should probably be changing your bed sheets more often than you already are.While thereaposs nothing better than hopping into a bed full of fresh sheets after sprucing up your bedroom, experts have claimed that the average person is not washing their bed linen enough. Although busy schedules can sometimes get in the way of giving your bed a refresh, experts at the Sleep Foundation have revealed that we should all be washing our bed sheets at least once a week - insisting that every couple of weeks doesnapost cut it.And in some cases, you should be washing your sheets even more than the recommended amount of once a week. Experts have suggested that someone who suffers from asthma or allergies should wash their sheets more frequently to improve overall wellbeing.  Andyouaposre someone who sleeps with a beloved dog or cat, then you should consider throwing your sheets in the washing up to twice a week to get rid of germs and bacteria that your furry friends may have carried from their outdoor adventures. If youaposre someone who likes to eat snacks when in bed, you should also be washing your sheets more than once a week. And people who go to bed without showering, or people who sleep naked, should also follow suit and stock up on some extra washing powder.  The biggest mistake many of us make is leaving our bedding on for more than a week, as they warn it leads to us apossleeping while surrounded by body oils, bacteria, dead skin cells, and dust mitesapos. Keeping your bed clean and hygienic can help thwart germs and allergens, and has even been found to help you sleep better. When it comes to your duvet, it doesnapost need washing as often as your sheets, but itaposs always good to give them a good clean every now and then - ideally every two months. Pillows should be washed at the same time, and the mattress itself should be given a clean down once a year. According to recent research, % of people are more excited to go to bed when their sheets are fresh and smell good. story: My mother-in-law always snoops through my stuff so I played a prank on herA woman took to Reddit to ask users whether she was out of order for playing a prank on her mum-in-law after her fiance got mad at her - but users were on her side Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman has asked whether she was in the wrong for playing a prank on her mum-in-law after she caught her snooping through her stuff. The woman explained that after being together for four years, her fiancé finally moved in with her. She bought her home seven years ago, so the majority of the furniture is hers, but theyaposre talking of aposmaking it a home for both of them.apos But sheaposs noticed when his mum comes over she snoops and goes through her stuff.Taking to Reddit, she said: One thing she snooped on was actually embarrassing. In my home office, I had a little aposaffirmationapos post-it note on my monitor saying aposI am smart, I am skilled, I am deserving of great thingsapos.It was a silly thing my therapist recommended to get me in a confident mindset before an interview. Anyway, she made a comment about my ego... So while wine drunk one night, she and her friend decided to write a few more aposaffirmationsapos to hide as a joke. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Some were: Medicine cabinet: My teeth will regrow! I am sharklike and powerful! Kitchen drawers: I know when to spoon, but I also know when to fork! I am sexy and self-assured! Work desk: I will not just f**k my way to the top of the company, I will f**k my way to the top of the world! Walk-in closet: I am beautul with clothes and without! Especially without! My boobs are legendary! The next time her mother-in-law came over, she saw a few and while she didnapost directly acknowledge them, she did start acting really strangely. I went to run some errands and when I was out, she confronted Al about the notes and was trying to tell him that I seemed unstable, egotistical, and moving in was a bad idea, she continued. She then showed him the notes and he didnapost really know what to make of it. He asked me and I said that they were just some silly private notes to boost my self-confidence and make myself laugh how had she gotten them  Had she been going through my things  He said she was just tidying, and saw them. And they were really weird. He askedI left them on purpose to annoy her, and I admitted that was kinda the joke, but I also have other weird or private s**t so what I said about her needing to stop snooping. He said I was making stuff hard for him, his mum was really protective and adjusting to him moving in with a girlfriend for the first time, and I was agitating her on purpose and making her think I wouldnapost be a good partner when he wanted her to have the opposite impression of me! She concluded her post by asking users whether she was out of order for playing the prank, and the majority of people were on her side as they slammed the mother-in-law for invading her privacy. While others criticised her fiance for not standing up for her. One person said: If you don’t set boundaries with your fiancé’s mother now, it’s going to be infinity times worse once you get married. Another wrote: It says a lot how he keeps defending her and chalks it up to be overprotectiveness. While I always hate to jump on the band wagon of aposomg this is immensely terrible you should break up over a moderate thingapos, I will say this is a red flag. A third commented: So you’ve been dating for four years. Are now engaged. And his mum is still uncertainyou’re right for each other  Someone  said: Itaposs such a light-hearted thing to do, surprised the joke flew over her head. Plus she wouldnapost have seen themshe hadnapost snooped apostidied.apos Maybe she is having trouble letting go of her son but silly notes arenapost cruel, theyaposre silly notes. While another added: Sheaposs snooping through your home. exchange between the pair.She captioned it: Told y’all that I was gonna quit :. Who the f**k asks somebody that not even a week after their goddamn mama died  I have to get used to not talking to my d*** mama every day, she continued. Would you die knowing you were a good f***ing person  Don’t answer that cause Iaposm blocking you. story: Full list of official Covid symptoms from cough and fever to muscle painAcross the coronavirus pandemic the symptoms Brits have suffered from has changed from iant to iant, with others claimed or reported onlineGlobally there are dozens of confirmed symptoms across the Covid iants Image: Getty ImagesByCorrie DavidKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsThroughout the pandemic, the Covid symptoms people have suffered have changed again and again from iant to iant.Whilst a continuous cough was the most known symptom early on, the latest Omicron ant has been more renowned with cold-like symptoms. According to the latest guidance, people who experience symptoms should get a PCR test as soon as they can,WalesOnline reports .But with lesser-known symptoms being reported widely on social media, it’s important to know what the official symptoms are, so people know when to request a PCR test. As stated, dferent iants have manested in dferent symptoms and dferent health bodies have released dfering lists of symptoms. So here’s a number of the dferent symptom lists from key health bodies and studies in one place.  NHS Covid symptomsNHS guidance has remained unchanged since the start of the pandemic, despite new iants leading to dferent symptoms. The three symptoms listed are: A high temperature – this means you feel hot to touch on your chest or backA new, continuous cough – this means coughing a lot for more than an hour or three or more coughing episodes in  hoursA loss or change to your sense of smell or taste – this means youaposve noticed you cannot smell or taste anything or things smell or taste dferent to normal The NHS also lists the same symptoms for children but it notes that cases amongst the young are usually less serious.  WHO Covid symptoms The World Health Organisation has noted that the virus affects people in dferent ways. They have broken down their list into common, less common, and serious symptoms. Most common symptoms are listed as:Fever Cough Tiredness Loss of taste or smell Less common symptoms are listed as:Sore throat Headache Aches and pains Diarrhoea A rash on skin or discolouration of fingers or toes Red or irritated eyes Serious symptoms are listed as:Dficulty breathing or shortness of breath Loss of speech or mobility or confusion Chest painThey recommended that those with serious symptoms should seek immediate medical attention but call aheadvisiting a hospital or doctor.
